title: Research Frontiers in Earth & Atmospheric Sciences I

Topics extend over a diversity of research areas in Earth & Atmospheric Sciences, with a consistent theme that many of the operative processes are intertwined and advances in elucidating them hinge on the adoption of an interdisciplinary framework.

Students will get familiar with the literature in the researches in Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.  3. Students will get familiar with the analytical and mathematical skills necessary in the researches.  4. Students will develop ability to communicate the results in the form of written reports, visual displays, and scientific presentations.

title: Solid and Fluid Mechanics
requirements:
For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
Not for students who have taken ESSC3010 or ESSC4010
description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth system science applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations; vorticity and divergence; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.
outcome: Students will acquire systematic training in continuum mechanics, a body of knowledge in mathematics and physics which is of critical importance in a diversity of earth system science applications, including geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography. The mathematical concepts are illustrated with geophysical examples. Students will be well equipped with useful background to pursue more advanced courses on physical aspects of earth system science.
syllabus: TopicsVectors. Cartesian coordinates. Vector algebra.Determinants. Change of orthonormal basis.Tensors. Principal values and principal directionsTraction and stress tensor. Principal stresses.Mohr’s circle.Current and reference configurations. Strain tensor.Infinitesimal strain tensor. Rigid body rotation.Transformation of integrals. Velocity gradient, strain rate and vorticity.Conservation of mass. Conservation of momentum. Conservation of energy. Ideal constitutive relations: inviscid fluid. Bernoulli’s equation. Potential flow. Ideal constitutive relations: viscous fluid. Steady and non-steady flow.Ideal constitutive relations: linear solid.Elastic waves and elasostatics.
required_readings: Rudnicki, J.W. (2015) Fundamentals of Continuum Mechanics, Wiley, 199 pp.
recommended_readings: Fung, Y.C., A First Course in Continuum Mechanics, 3rd ed., Prentice-Hall, 1994.Mase, G.E. (1999), Continuum Mechanics for Engineers, CRC Press, 377 pp.Schey, H.M. (2005),  Div, Grad, Curl, and All That: An Informal Text on Vector Calculus, Norton, 163 pp.Bradford Hager: Course notes of MIT 12.005 Applications of Continuum Mechanics to Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences (2006).James Hansen: Course notes of MIT 12.800 Fluid Dynamics of the Atmosphere and Ocean (2004)

title: Rock and Soil Mechanics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: A survey of basic concepts of rock and soil mechanics: Classification and physical properties of soil and rock; stress and strain; pore pressure, seepage and effective stress; laboratory measurement of deformation and strength; failure mode and criteria; in situ stress and measurement; soil consolidation; mechanical behavior of rock discontinuity. Geotechnical applications: shallow and deep foundations; retaining structures; slope instability; underground excavation.
outcome: 1. An understanding of the basics of poromechanics: stress and strain, pore pressure and effective stress, strength and failure criteria.2. Knowledge of the classification and physical properties of soil and rock.3. A basic understanding of the mechanics of soil and rock deformation, soil consolidation and shear failure, and modes of failure of intact rocks and discontinuities.4. An appreciation of the application of soil and rock mechanics to geotechnical engineering.

requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: Knowledge of aerosol physics and chemistry such as condensation and evaporation; thermodynamics; radiative, hygroscopic properties, and cloud formation potential of aerosols;Recent advances in aerosol physics and chemistry researches; Roles of atmospheric aerosols on the critical environmental issues such as air quality, tropospheric smog, and climate change, with focus on observations, laboratory measurements and modelling.
outcome: 1. Students will learn how various important atmospheric physical processes alter the composition and properties of atmospheric aerosols  2. title: Advanced Topics in Global Environmental Change
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This interdisciplinary course presents and discusses recent scientific advances in the fundamental understanding of environmental issues including climate change, changes in ecosystems due to loss of biodiversity, changes in hydrological systems and the supplies of freshwater, land degradation, urbanization, and stresses on food-producing systems.

title: Applied Geophysics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course introduces concepts, principles, and applications of geophysical methods in environmental and engineering studies. It offers an overall survey of various geophysical methods for exploring the shallow subsurface. It provides the technical foundation needed to understand the use and limitations of gravity, seismic, ground penetrating radar, and electromagnetic methods. Demonstration of commonly used methods will be provided in the field along with tutorials of preliminary data analysis techniques. Technical papers published in leading applied geophysics journals will be discussed in reading groups.
outcome: - Students will become familiar with applied geophysics methods, their principles, and their typical applications - Students will gain a solid understanding of physical properties of soil and rocks determining geophysical properties - Students will design and conduct geophysics field surveys, process, analyze, and interpret survey data using computer software - Students will understand the advantages and limitations of geophysical methods when applied to environmental and engineering studies - Students will critically understand and judge technical papers published in leading applied geophysics journals

title: Petrology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth System Science because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).
outcome: Students are expected to gain the following abilities:1. Gain the skills to identify different rock types (igneous and metamorphic basically).2. Good knowledge of typical mineral assemblages of different rocks.3. Use optical polarizing microscope to distinguish: (1) different minerals based on their optical properties, (2) typical igneous and metamorphic micro-textures and structures, (3) featured mineral assemblages corresponding to different P-T conditions. 4. Understand phase equilibrium and phase rule and their applications in understanding the rock forming process.5. Understand different metamorphic facies and their significance of variable tectonic settings.6. Use petrologic concepts and theories to address topics of societal interests, including natural hazards, natural resources, and human health issues.The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
syllabus: Introduction and practice of Electronic Microscope for Petrologic Study Phase Rule Igneous Petrology Sedimentary Petrology Metamorphic Petrology

title: Geomorphology
requirements:
For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences or grant the approval from course coordinator
Pre-requisite: ESSC2010 and ESSC3100 or equivalent courses
description: This course is an important part of the core Earth System Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the main concepts in geomorphology with emphasis on understanding the coupling of environments, processes and materials that leads to landform development. Understanding the underlying geological principles of rocks, minerals, structural deformation and geological time are important background knowledge to be enhanced by the study of geomorphology.It discusses the qualitative and quantitative techniques for investigation and research in the field, laboratory, and computer modeling. The application of geomorphology for public safety, engineering problems and development of sustainable solutions will be emphasized. Examples from theory and practice of geomorphology in Hong Kong will be introduced. Practical understanding and skills will be gained from lab exercises and field trips in Hong Kong.Students are suggested to be equipped with basic knowledge of rocks and minerals, structural geology and geological time scale.
outcome: Students are expected to gain the following abilities: 1. Understand the relationships between materials, processes and landforms; 2. Use concepts of solid and fluid mechanics to interpret the formation of landforms; 3. Use graphical tools to compile and interpret field and laboratory data; 4. Integrate topics in mineralogy, petrology, structural geology, plate tectonics, climate sciences, biogeosciences, hydrology, remote sensing and geotechnical engineering through survey of scientific literature, case studies, books and textbooks; and 5. Make primary observations in the field and using them to construct and test hypotheses.  Lectures focus on physical and chemical aspects of landform evolution and understanding spatial patterns in landscapes and how humans affect and are impacted by Earth surface processes. Labs use the geological maps, terrain classification maps, aerial photography interpretation, societal consequence assessment, and physical models to illustrate these concepts.  Students are encouraged to ask, follow-up research and lead discussion of questions regarding lecture topics throughout the semester. Field trips in the second half of the semester encourage small-group discussion of observations and interpretations of landscape evolution and human impacts in mountainous and coastal terrains. The students will develop the ability: 1) to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students will also be challenged to manage a large amount of reading in short periods of time and to think of their role as a citizen and in society.

title: Seismology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of elastic wave propagation and physics of earthquake. The topics covered include the Earth’s internal structure, material elasticity, travel time tomography, seismic ray theory, ray tracing, and earthquake source parameter. Methods and field practice of seismological survey and programming methods of data processing will also be introduced.
outcome: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to know about Earth’s inner structure, understand principles of elastic wave propagation and earthquake physics, seismic imaging, as well as seismic exploration. The students will also be trained with extensive computing exercises. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

title: Marine Geology and Geophysics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of marine geology and geophysics. Marine geology is distinct from that of continent and is the important foundation to launch Plate Tectonics, the modern unified theory of the Earth. In this course, major components of marine geological settings such as mid-ocean ridges, transform faults, subduction zones, oceanic lithosphere, and etc. will be introduced and discussed in details. Methods of geophysical survey will also be introduced. Field experiments of scientific instruments such as Ocean Bottom Seismometers, marine magnetometer and gravimeter will be conducted. A geological field trip will also be included. This course will be jointly offered with Ocean College, Zhejiang University, as an initiative to develop ocean sciences at CUHK.

title: Earthquake Source Physics
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course focuses on the concepts and theory of earthquake source physics. The topics covered include seismic instrumentation, geophysical observations of earthquake source processes, kinematic source representation of earthquakes, dynamic rupture propagation of earthquakes, frictional properties of fault zones, and entire earthquake cycle. Methods and field practice of seismological survey will also be introduced.

title: Land-Atmosphere Interactions and Boundary-Layer Meteorology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course introduces the physical, chemical and biological processes governing the exchange of energy, momentum, water and other chemical materials between the atmosphere and land surface, including a formal introduction into boundary-layer meteorology. Topics covered include the basic equations and concepts of heat, momentum and mass conservation and transfer at the land-atmosphere interface; soil physics and hydrometeorology; temperature, humidity and wind distribution in the atmospheric boundary layer; theories and observations of turbulence; stability and boundary-layer dynamics; biometeorology and ecophysiology of land plants; canopy and ecosystem exchange; and land use change and urbanization. Applications to weather phenomena, air pollution, forestry, agriculture and ecosystem management will be emphasized throughout.
outcome: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain knowledge of physical and chemical processes of land-atmosphere interactions and boundary layer dynamics; and 2) Develop the skill and ability to understand climate variability related to land-atmosphere interactions. (Course Outcomes as related to Programme Learning Outcomes) -- The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

title: Tropical Meteorology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course introduces the phenomena and motions in the tropical atmosphere. The topics covered include the role of the tropics in the global energy and momentum balance, ITCZ, subtropical high, upper-level anticyclones, weather and climate phenomena including meso-scale convective systems, tropical waves, the Hadley and the Walker circulation, El Nino-Southern Oscillation, tropical cyclones, Madden Julian Oscillation, and monsoons.
outcome: At the completion of this course, the students will be able to 1) Gain the knowledge of various tropical atmospheric motions, 2) Understand physical processes in the tropical atmosphere; and 3) Apply knowledge to understand tropical climate variability. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
syllabus: •Radiative and convection: Radiative Processes in the Tropics, Surface Energy Balance, Top of the Atmosphere Net Radiation Fluxes, Dry and Moist Stability, Moist Convection •General circulation in the tropics: Observed zonally averaged Tropical circulation, Theory of the Hadley Cell, Zonally asymmetric circulation features, seasonal variations, diurnal cycle, Observed aspects of the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ), ITCZ theory, Gill model, Heat lows •Monsoons: Deﬁnition, Differential Heating and the Monsoon, Key Elements of the Asian Summer and Winter Monsoon , Onset and Withdrawal, Breaks in the Indian Monsoon •El Nino and Southern Oscillation (ENSO): Observational aspect, air-sea interaction, teleconnection, ENSO modeling •Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO): Observational aspect, Theory of MJO, Westerly wind bursts, Connection with ENSO •Tropical Waves and Tropical Depressions (TD): Matsuno wave theory, convective coupled equatorial waves, easterly waves and TD-type disturbances, relationship with Tropical Cyclones (TC) genesis •TC: Structure, Genesis, dynamics of TC movement, and intensiﬁcation, modeling and forecasting •Tropical Squall Lines and Mesoscale Convective Systems (MCS): Observations of MCS and squall lines, dynamical aspects, Organization of Convection
required_readings: Krishnamurti, T.N., Stefanova, Lydia, Misra, Vasubandhu, 2013: Tropical Meteorology- An Introduction. Springer.

title: Air Pollution Science and Engineering
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course will cover a variety of topics related to air pollution science and engineering. Topics include: indoor and outdoor air quality (including particulate matters (PM) and gases pollutants); air pollution measurement and statistics; air quality meteorology and dispersion models; principles and challenges of air pollution control and measurement.
outcome: 1) To understand the physical and chemical principles governing the sources, formation, transport, transformation, health impacts of air pollutants in both indoor and outdoor environments.2) To understand the working principles of various air pollution monitoring instrumentation.3) To apply statistical tools and mathematical models to solve air pollutant dispersion problems.4) To apply various air pollution engineering approaches to solve air pollution issues.5) To gain a better understanding of current air pollution problems and control challenges.

title: Urban Climatology
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change.
outcome: Students are expected to attain the knowledge about how urbanisation affects the local climate and the underlying processes. They should also be able to: 1.  describe the scientific processes and explain the theories of how urbanisation alters local climate; 2.  explain the physical mechanisms governing the formation of urban climatic phenomena; 3.  conduct numerical modelling and field experiments of urban climatic processes; and 4.  understand the practical implications of urban climatology on climate-sensitive urban planning and design.
syllabus: Topic and Content/Fundamental concept Week 1 Lecture 1: Introduction to urbanisation and urban climate Week 2 Lecture 2: Fundamentals of urban climatology I •  Urban boundary layer (UBL) and urban canopy layer (UCL) •  Urban climatic processes within UBL and UCL Week 3 Lecture 3: Fundamentals of urban climatology II •  Heterogeneity of urban surface environment •  Atmospheric turbulence and exchange of energy and water Week 4 Lecture 4: Urban energy balance I •  Anthropogenic heat flux •  Urban radiation balance Week 5 Lecture 5: Urban energy balance II •  Urban canopy energy balance •  Urban neighbourhood energy balance Week 6 Lab 1: Urban Multi-scale Environmental Predictor (UMEP): An integrated tool for city-based climate services Week 7 Lecture 6: Urban heat islands – History and physical basis •  Detection of urban heat island: Luke Howard in 1810s •  Determinants of heat island magnitude and structure •  Diversity of urban heat island Week 8 Lecture 7: Monitoring urban heat islands •  Ground-level meteorological measurements •  Mobile measurements •  Land surface temperature Week 9 Lecture 8: Urban heat islands – Examples of different climatic regions •  Tropical climates: Singapore and India •  Sub-tropical climates: Hong Kong and South Africa •  Mediterranean climates: Greece and Spain •  High-latitude climates: Sweden and the United Kingdom Week 10 Lecture 9: Urban climatic mapping •  Urban climatic maps – History, development, and applications •  Local climatic zones – Classification of surface environment Week 11 Lecture 10: Application of urban climatology in climate-sensitive urban planning and design •  Why urban planning and design matters? •  Air Ventilation Assessment System •  Sustainable Building Design Guidelines Week 12 Lab 2: Mapping of local climatic zones using WUDAPT methodology Week 13 Lecture 11: Cities and climate change

title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth system science. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data. Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.
outcome: Students will become knowledgeable about the acquisition, pre-processing and analysis of geophysical and environmental data, including remote sensing, in situ observation and model data. Students will acquire knowledge on techniques for data processing, including visualization methods and statistical analysis, and on the applications of these data and tools to geophysical and environmental problems. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students can also acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
syllabus: Exploratory Data Analysis Correlation Analysis Parametric Probability Distribution : Discrete Parametric Probability Distribution : Continuous Hypothesis Testing Frequentist Statistical Inference: Resampling Methods Statistical Forecasting: Simple Linear Regression Statistical Forecasting: Multiple Linear Regression, Non-Linear Regression Statistical Forecasting: Predictor Selection, Ensemble Forecasting Linear algebra and matrix inverse Quantifying preconceptions: Bayesian inference Quantifying preconceptions: Prior information Detecting periodicities: Sinusoidal functions and Fourier series Detecting periodicities: Complex Fourier series and Fourier transform The past influences the present: Convolution The past influences the present: Filters Cross-correlation Bandpass filters and windowing Filling in missing data Approximation Principal Component Analysis I Time Series Analysis Forecast Verification
required_readings: Refer to the course syllabus distributed in the class.
recommended_readings: Wilks, D.S., Statistical Methods in the Atmospheric Sciences, 3rd edition, AP, 2011.Menke, W., Environmental Data Analysis with Matlab, 2nd edition, AP, 2016

title: Numerical Methods and Modeling for Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: This course covers the principles of numerical methods and modeling relevant for earth and atmospheric sciences applications. Topics include: optimization; interpolation; finite differencing; numerical solutions to ordinary and partial differential equations; programming numerical models; filtered models; boundary conditions; subgrid-scale processes; data assimilation; applications in earthquake, climate, air quality, weather forecast and groundwater models. Python will be used in this course.
outcome: Students will understand the principles and acquire the important skills in numerical methods and modeling, with knowledge of basic programming. The various methods learned are widely used in geoscientific applications including earthquake, weather and climate predictions.
syllabus: Introduction & Governing Equations Assumptions and Coordinates Finite Differencing (1) Finite Differencing (2) Programming Numerical Models Barotropic Primitive Equation Models Boundary Conditions Subgrid-scale Processes Model Initialization (Data Assimilation) Methods of Solving Chemical Equations Geophysical Modeling

title: Remote Sensing – Principles and Applications
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: Remote sensing observations are critical for monitoring regional and global changes, determining spatial and temporal variability of the Earth System, and addressing fundamental global issues. This course introduces the basic physical principles of remote sensing, including electromagnetic waves and radiation, optical, microwave, and non-imaging remote sensing. It also presents key concepts and examples on remote sensing applications in Earth system science, such as the (atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere), and global changes. This course also provides computer-based lab exercises that facilitate the understanding of remote sensing principles and the processing of remote sensing data.
outcome: This course will contribute to understanding of basic concepts and principles of remote sensing at optical and microwave frequencies from airborne and spaceborne platforms. With the help from laboratory analysis and case studies, remote sensing applications in Earth system science can be further understood. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
syllabus: Week   Topics1          Introduction, Remote sensing platforms2          Electromagnetic waves and radiation, Electromagnetic interaction with matters3          Radiative Transfer4          Photogrammetry and stereogrammetry, Structure from Motion5          Optical sensors6          Remote Sensing Data Processing I: ENVI, color compositive, band math7          Passive microwave remote sensing8          Active remote sensing: Radar ranging9          Active remote sensing: LiDAR ranging10        Remote Sensing Data Processing II: data fitting11        Synthetic Aperture Radar, Interferometric SAR12        Remote Sensing Data Processing III: image processing, filtering13        Remote Sensing Data Processing IV: change detection, classification14        Machine learning and deep learning in remote sensing
required_readings: Emery W. and Camps A., Introduction to Satellite Remote Sensing, 1st edition. Elsevier, 2017. Physical principles of remote sensing, 3rd edition, W.G. Rees, Cambridge University Press, 2013.
recommended_readings: Sabins, F., Remote Sensing: Principles and Interpretation, 3rd edition, Waveland Pr Inc;, 2007. Mather, Paul M., Computer processing of Remotely-Sensed Images, Wiley, 2011.
